Introduction

Febrile seizures are the most common type of seizure in children.  They are characterized by seizures that occur in association with a fever, usually in the context of a viral infection.  Although they can appear alarming, febrile seizures are generally benign and do not indicate a serious underlying neurologic condition.

Pathophysiology



Seizures are the result of hypersynchronous excitatory activity of neurons located within the cortex.  The exact reason for seizures occurring specifically in the setting of febrile illness in children is not fully understood, but it is perhaps related to a combination of a lower seizure threshold during the early years of brain development and a rapidly increasing temperature in the brain leading to increased neuronal firing.  There appears to be a genetic susceptibility as well, although mutations are not always identifiable.

Risk factors



Children age 6 months to 5 years are almost exclusively affected, likely because the seizure threshold is lower during the early years of brain development.  In addition, young children are particularly susceptible to viral illnesses (eg, roseola [human herpesvirus 6], influenza) associated with high fever (â‰¥39.5 C [103.1 F]), a key risk factor for development of these seizures.  Children with a family history of febrile seizures or epilepsy have a slightly increased risk.

Clinical presentation



Febrile seizures typically occur during the first day of a viral illness.  Patients may have findings consistent with infection (eg, rhinorrhea, tachycardia, tachypnea); however, febrile seizures may be the initial manifestation of an infection, occurring just prior to the onset of viral symptoms.  A simple febrile seizure is characterized by:



  • Generalized, nonfocal movements (eg, unresponsiveness with full-body tonic-clonic movements)
  • Short duration (<15 min)
  • No recurrence within 24 hours


Postictal drowsiness can be present, typically lasting up to 10 minutes.  Patients with febrile seizures have no previous afebrile seizure, no evidence of metabolic disease (eg, asterixis, depressed sensorium), and no signs of intracranial infection (eg, neck stiffness, bulging fontanelle, photophobia).

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of febrile seizures is made clinically based on a combination of classic history and normal physical examination.  Patients do not require diagnostic studies to evaluate their febrile seizures.

Differential diagnosis



The most important diagnosis to differentiate from febrile seizures is meningitis (

).  Red flag findings on examination that may suggest meningitis should prompt immediate lumbar puncture.  These findings include:



  • Age outside typical febrile seizure range of 6 months to 5 years
  • Signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, morning headache, vomiting, bulging fontanelle)
  • Meningeal signs (eg, nuchal rigidity)
  • Prolonged altered mental status (postictal period >10 min)
  • Petechial rash (suggestive of Neisseria meningitidis)


Other considerations in the decision to perform lumbar puncture include current antibiotic therapy, which can mask meningitis symptoms, or incomplete vaccination history.



Febrile seizures lasting >15 minutes, have focal features, or occur in clusters (eg, complex febrile seizures), as well as seizures without fever, require further evaluation.  These can be differentiated from simple febrile seizures clinically.

Management



Treatment of simple febrile seizures typically involves parental reassurance.  Benzodiazepines can be used to abort seizures lasting â‰¥5 minutes; however, most self-resolve prior to presentation.  Parents should be informed that febrile seizures are common and self-limited, without acute or long-term sequelae.  Antipyretics are administered for general fever reduction, but they do not prevent future febrile seizures.

Prognosis



Families should be educated that febrile seizures often recur (in 30% of patients) and that although the risk for epilepsy is slightly increased, the overall risk remains low (~1%).  Typically, febrile seizures that recur eventually resolve spontaneously by school age and have no impact on development.

Febrile seizures (
